Above them is the number '22' in red. | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Phil Lord and Christopher Miller|Phil Lord
Christopher Miller]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * [[Neal H. Moritz]] * [[Jonah Hill]] * [[Channing Tatum]] }} | screenplay = {{Plainlist| * [[Michael Bacall]] * Oren Uziel * [[Rodney Rothman]] }} | story = {{Plainlist| * Michael Bacall * Jonah Hill }} | based on = {{Based on|''[[21 Jump Street]]''|[[Patrick Hasburgh]]
[[Stephen J. Cannell]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * Jonah Hill * Channing Tatum * [[Peter Stormare]] * [[Ice Cube]] }} | music = [[Mark Mothersbaugh]] | cinematography = [[Barry Peterson (cinematographer)|Barry Peterson]] | editing = {{Plainlist| * [[David Rennie (editor)|David Rennie]] * Keith Brachmann }} | production companies = {{Plainlist| * [[LStar Capital]] * [[Media Rights Capital]] * [[Original Film]] * [[The Cannell Studios]] * Storyville * 75 Year Plan Productions }} | distributor = {{Plainlist| * [[Columbia Pictures]] * [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] }} | released = {{Film date|2014|06|04|[[New York City]]|2014|06|13|United States}} | runtime = 112 minutes{{cite web |title=22 Jump Street |url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/22-jump-street-film |publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]] |date=May 23, 2014 |accessdate=May 28, 2014}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = $50–84.5 million{{Cite journal|last=FilmL.A.|title=2014 Feature Film Study|url=https://www.filmla.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/2014_FeatureFilm_study_v10_WEB.pdf|journal=FilmL.A. Feature Film Study|date=May 2015|accessdate=April 19, 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://fastlane.louisianaeconomicdevelopment.com/Film/FilmSearchDetails.aspx?ProjNum=VCPHNNs1db1807DgywngyQ%3d%3d|title=22 Jump Street Budget Info|last=|first=|date=March 13, 2014|website=Louisiana Economic Development|publisher=|access-date=August 9, 2016}}{{Cite web|url=https://wikileaks.org/sony/docs/03_03/RISKMGMT/Production%20Files/22%20Jump%20Street%20%20(9-29-13%20to%2012-18-13)/Budget/22JS%20Budget%2015%20131008_FINAL%20BUDGET%20top%20sheet.pdf|title=22 Jumps Street Budget|last=|first=|date=October 10, 2013|website=Wikileaks|publisher=|access-date=August 9, 2016}} | gross = $331.3 million{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=21jumpstreet2.htm|title=22 Jump Street (2014)|website=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=November 20, 2014}} }} '''''22 Jump Street''''' is a 2014 American [[action film|action]] [[comedy film]] directed by [[Phil Lord and Christopher Miller]], written by [[Jonah Hill]], [[Michael Bacall]], Oren Uziel and [[Rodney Rothman]] and produced by and starring Hill and [[Channing Tatum]]. [[Ice Cube]], [[Peter Stormare]], [[Jillian Bell]], [[Amber Stevens West]] and [[Wyatt Russell]] also star. It is the [[sequel]] to the 2012 film ''[[21 Jump Street (film)|21 Jump Street]]'', based on the [[21 Jump Street|television series of the same name]]. The plot follows police officers Morton Schmidt and Greg Jenko as they go undercover at a college in order to find the supplier of a new drug. Plans for a ''Jump Street'' sequel began the week of the first film's release. Hill and Tatum were quickly confirmed to be reprising their roles, while Miller and Lord announced they'd be returning to direct in July 2013. Filming took place from September to December 2013 in [[New Orleans]], Louisiana, as well as [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]]. ''22 Jump Street'' was released on June 13, 2014, by [[Columbia Pictures]] and [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]]. The film received positive reviews, with some critics calling it one of the best comedy sequels of all time, and grossed $331 million worldwide. ==Plot== Two years following their success in the 21 Jump Street program, Schmidt ([[Jonah Hill]]) and Jenko ([[Channing Tatum]]) are back on the streets chasing narcotics. However, after failing in the pursuit of a group of drug dealers led by Ghost ([[Peter Stormare]]), Deputy Chief Hardy ([[Nick Offerman]]) puts the duo back on the program to work for Captain Dickson ([[Ice Cube]]) – now located across the street at 22 Jump Street. Their assignment is to go undercover as college students and locate the supplier of a drug known as "WHY-PHY" (Work Hard? Yes, Play Hard? Yes) that killed a student photographed buying it on campus from a dealer. At college, Jenko quickly makes friends with a pair of jocks named Zook ([[Wyatt Russell]]) and Rooster ([[Jimmy Tatro]]), they later become the prime suspects of the investigation. Jenko starts attending parties with the jocks who do not take as kindly to Schmidt. Meanwhile, Schmidt gets the attention of an art student, Maya ([[Amber Stevens]]), by feigning an interest in slam poetry. The two sleep together, to the disapproval of Maya's roommate Mercedes ([[Jillian Bell]]), and Schmidt later finds that Maya is the daughter of Captain Dickson, whom Schmidt bragged to about "getting laid", much to Dickson's fury. Despite sleeping together, Maya tells Schmidt not to take it seriously, and he starts to feel left out as Jenko bonds more and more with Zook who encourages him to join the football team. When Schmidt and Jenko are unable to identify the dealer, they visit Mr. Walters ([[Rob Riggle]]) and Eric ([[Dave Franco]]) in jail for advice. After confessing the two are having regular intercourse, Walters points out a unique tattoo on the arm of the dealer in the photograph. Whilst hanging out with Zook and Rooster, Jenko notices that Rooster does not have the tattoo but sees it on Zook's arm. Schmidt and Jenko are invited to join the fraternity led by the jocks, but Schmidt refuses, furthering the tension between the two as Jenko passes their requirements. They later realize that Zook is not the dealer but rather another customer. Soon afterwards, they find Ghost and his men on campus, but Ghost again evades them. Jenko reveals to Schmidt that he has been offered a football scholarship with Zook and is uncertain about his future as a police officer. Afterwards, Schmidt reveals his true identity and moves out of the dorm, angering Maya. Spring break arrives, and Schmidt goes after Ghost. He is joined by Jenko, so the two can have one final mission together. The pair head to the beach where Ghost is likely to be dealing WHY-PHY. Inside a bar, they find Mercedes, who is Ghost's daughter, giving instructions to other dealers. The pair, backed up by Dickson and the rest of Jump Street, ambush the meeting. Ghost flees, while Mercedes is knocked out by Schmidt. While pursuing Ghost, Jenko is shot in the shoulder. Ghost attempts to escape in a helicopter; Schmidt and Jenko manage to jump across to it, but they fall into the sea due to Jenko's injured arm. However, Jenko is able to throw a grenade into the helicopter. Ghost celebrates his victory prematurely while the grenade explodes, sending the totalled remains into the sea. Jenko tells Schmidt that he still wants to be a police officer as he believes their differences help their partnership, and the two reconcile in front of a cheering crowd. Dickson approaches them claiming to have a new mission undercover at a med school. During the credits, Jenko and Schmidt go on to a variety of undercover missions to different schools, which are portrayed as fictional sequels, an animated series, and a toy line. One mission features [[Booker (TV series)|Detective Booker]] ([[Richard Grieco]]) while another sees the return of Ghost, who survived the helicopter explosion. In a post-credits scene, Walters reveals to Eric that he is [[menstrual cycle|late]], implying he is pregnant. ==Cast== {{div col}} * [[Jonah Hill]] as Officer Morton Schmidt/Doug McQuaid{{cite web |url=http://www.hotmovie.info/movies/3227-22-jump-street |title=22 Jump Street |publisher=[[Sony Pictures Entertainment]] |accessdate=June 11, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714130104/http://www.hotmovie.info/movies/3227-22-jump-street |archivedate=July 14, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} * [[Channing Tatum]] as Officer Greg Jenko/Brad McQuaid * [[Peter Stormare]]{{cite web|url=http://www.22jumpstreetmovie.com/site/ |title=22 Jump Street |publisher=[[Sony Pictures Entertainment]] |accessdate=May 21, 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sKrvtP9c-1U |title=22 Jump Street Clip: "Undercover" |publisher=[[Sony Pictures Entertainment]] |date=April 14, 2014 |accessdate=May 21, 2014}} as Ghost * [[Ice Cube]] as Captain Dickson, Maya’s father * [[Amber Stevens West]]{{cite news |first=Justin |last=Kroll |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sns-201309061500reedbusivarietyn1200601582-20130906,0,3522482.story |title=Amber Stevens Signs Up For '22 Jump Street' |work=Chicago Tribune |date=September 6, 2013 |accessdate=October 1, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131216204404/http://www.chicagotribune.com/sns-201309061500reedbusivarietyn1200601582-20130906,0,3522482.story |archivedate=December 16, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} as Maya * [[Wyatt Russell]] as Zook Haythe * [[Jillian Bell]]{{cite web|url=http://www.thewrap.com/workaholics-star-jillian-bell-joins-jonah-hill-channing-tatum-in-22-jump-street-exclusive/ |title='Workaholics' Star Jillian Bell Joins Jonah Hill, Channing Tatum in '22 Jump Street' (Exclusive) |work=TheWrap |date=September 12, 2013 |accessdate=February 10, 2014}} as Mercedes * [[Jimmy Tatro]] as Rooster * [[Craig Roberts]] as Spencer * [[Nick Offerman]] as Deputy Chief Hardy * [[Dave Franco]] as Eric Molson (uncredited) * [[Rob Riggle]] as Mr. Walters (uncredited) * [[Marc Evan Jackson]] as Dr. Murphy{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/new/22-Jump-Street-Delivers-Hysterical-Footage-CinemaCon-42278.html|title=22 Jump Street Delivers Hysterical New Footage At CinemaCon|publisher=CinemaBlend|date=March 27, 2014|accessdate=April 29, 2014}} * [[Kenny and Keith Lucas]] as Kenny and Keith Yang * [[Queen Latifah]] as Mrs. Dickson (uncredited) * [[Diplo]] as Himself * [[Dustin Nguyen]] as Vietnamese Jesus * [[Richard Grieco]] as Dennis Booker * [[H. Jon Benjamin]] as MCS Football Coach (uncredited){{cite web|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/57276/10-things-know-about-22-jump-street|title=10 Things to Know About '22 Jump Street'|publisher=MentalFloss.com|first=Erin|last=McCarthy|accessdate=March 24, 2016}} * [[Patton Oswalt]] as MC State History Professor (uncredited) * [[Bill Hader]] as Culinary School Villain (uncredited) * [[Anna Faris]] as Anna (uncredited){{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1844906/22-jump-street-easter-eggs/|title=’22 JUMP STREET’: 9 EASTER EGGS AND CAMEOS YOU MIGHT HAVE MISSED|publisher=[[MTV]]|first=Alex|last=Zalben|date=June 13, 2014|accessdate=March 24, 2016}} * [[Seth Rogen]] as a Morton Schmidt double (uncredited) {{div col end}} ==Production== On March 17, 2012, [[Sony Pictures]] announced that it was pursuing a sequel to ''[[21 Jump Street (film)|21 Jump Street]]'', signing a deal that would see [[Jonah Hill]] and [[Michael Bacall]] return to write a [[Film treatment|script treatment]] that would be again developed by Bacall.{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/21-jump-street-2-sequel-men-in-black-4/182069/ |title=Sony Pictures Planning JUMANJI Reboot; MEN IN BLACK 4; Will Shoot 21 JUMP STREET Sequel in the Fall |work=Collider |date=September 25, 2013 |accessdate=October 1, 2013}} The film was originally scheduled to be released on June 6, 2014.{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/men-black-4-21-jump-451611 |title='Men in Black 4,' '21 Jump Street' Sequel in Development at Sony |publisher=Hollywoodreporter.com |date= May 3, 2013|accessdate=October 1, 2013 |first=Borys |last=Kit}} On May 8, 2013, it was announced that the film would be pushed back a week until June 13, 2014.{{cite web |url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=103977 |title=21 Jump Street 2 Takes Jurassic Park 4's Old Date |website=ComingSoon.net |date=May 8, 2013 |accessdate=September 28, 2013}} In June 2013, it was announced the film would be titled ''22 Jump Street''.{{cite news|last=Chitwood|first=Adam|title=21 Jump Street Sequel Titled 22 Jump Street|url=http://collider.com/21-jump-street-sequel-22-jump-street/|accessdate=June 17, 2013|newspaper=Collider.com|date=June 5, 2013}} In July 2013, [[Phil Lord and Christopher Miller]] confirmed they would return to direct the film.{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/21-jump-street-2-sequel-news-phil-lord-chris-miller/ |title=22 JUMP STREET News: Phil Lord and Chris Miller Confirm They’re Directing, Explain the Sequel's Title, and More |publisher=Collider |date=July 30, 2013 |accessdate=October 1, 2013}} On September 6, 2013, [[Amber Stevens]] joined the cast of the film. On September 27, 2013, [[Kurt Russell]] mentioned that his son [[Wyatt Russell|Wyatt]] turned down a role for [[The Hunger Games (film series)|''The Hunger Games'' sequels]] to star in ''22 Jump Street''.{{cite web |url=http://www.contactmusic.com/story/kurt-russell-my-son-turned-down-hunger-games-for-21-jump-street-2_3883366 |title=Kurt Russell: 'Mỹ Sơn Turned Down Hunger Games For 21 Jump Street 2' |publisher=Contactmusic.com |date=September 27, 2013 |accessdate=September 28, 2013}} [[Principal photography]] began on September 28, 2013, in [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]], with shots in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]] as well (acting for the shots in the movie as the spring break in "Puerto Mexico") and ended on December 15, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=109591 |title=22 Jump Street Starts Shooting for Sony Pictures and MGM |website=ComingSoon.net |date= |accessdate=October 1, 2013}}{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/JonahHill/status/412395724878270465 |title=JonahHill: Just wrapped #22jumpstreet |publisher=Twitter.com |date= |accessdate=January 6, 2014}} The end titles, featuring satirical concepts for an ongoing series of Jump Street films and merchandise, were designed by the studio Alma Mater.{{cite web|last1=R. Taylor|first1=Noah|title=Art of the Title: 22 Jump Street|url=http://www.artofthetitle.com/title/22-jump-street/|website=Art of the Title|accessdate=March 26, 2015}} ==Music== {{see also|22 Jump Street (Original Motion Picture Score)}} The score for the film was composed by [[Mark Mothersbaugh]] and was released by La-La Land Records on a double disc album, limited to 2,000 copies, in September 2014. The second disc of the album also contains the score from the film's predecessor, ''[[21 Jump Street (film)|21 Jump Street]]'', composed by Mothersbaugh as well.{{cite web|title=Mark Mothersbaugh's Scores for ’21 Jump Street’ and ’22 Jump Street’ Released|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2014/09/23/mark-mothersbaughs-scores-for-21-jump-street-and-22-jump-street-released/|publisher=FilmMusicReporter.com|accessdate=November 1, 2014}} ==Release== ===Box office=== ''22 Jump Street'' grossed $191.7 million in North America and $139.4 million in other countries for a worldwide total of $331.3 million, against a budget of $84.5 million.{{Cite web|url=https://fastlane.louisianaeconomicdevelopment.com/Film/FilmSearchDetails.aspx?ProjNum=VCPHNNs1db1807DgywngyQ%3d%3d|title=22 Jump Street Budget Info|last=|first=|date=March 13, 2014|website=Louisiana Economic Development|publisher=|access-date=August 9, 2016}}{{Cite web|url=https://wikileaks.org/sony/docs/03_03/RISKMGMT/Production%20Files/22%20Jump%20Street%20%20(9-29-13%20to%2012-18-13)/Budget/22JS%20Budget%2015%20131008_FINAL%20BUDGET%20top%20sheet.pdf|title=22 Jumps Street Budget|last=|first=|date=October 10, 2013|website=Wikileaks|publisher=|access-date=August 9, 2016}} It outgrossed the first ''Jump Street'' film, which made a total of $201.6 million during its theatrical run.{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=21jumpstreet.htm | title=21 Jump Street (2012) | website=[[Box Office Mojo]] | accessdate=March 25, 2015}} ''22 Jump Street'' grossed $5.5 million at its early Thursday night showings.{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-22-jump-street-711696 |title=Box Office: '22 Jump Street' Opens to Stellar $5.5 Million Thursday Night |publisher=The Hollywood Reporter |date= |accessdate=June 14, 2014}} On its opening day it grossed $25 million, including the early Thursday showings.{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2014/06/14/box-office-22-jump-street-nabs-25m-how-to-train-your-dragon-2-nabs-18-5m-on-friday/ |title=Friday Box Office: '22 Jump Street' – $25M, 'How To Train Your Dragon 2' – $18.5M |publisher=Forbes |date=May 28, 2014 |accessdate=June 14, 2014 |first=Scott |last=Mendelson}} In North America, the film opened at number one in its first weekend, with $57.1 million.{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?yr=2014&wknd=24&p=.htm |title=Weekend Box Office Results for June 13–15, 2014 |website=Box Office Mojo |date= |accessdate=June 15, 2014}} In its second weekend, the film dropped to number two, grossing an additional $27.5 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?yr=2014&wknd=25&p=.htm |title=Weekend Box Office Results for June 20–22, 2014 |website=Box Office Mojo |date= |accessdate=June 24, 2014}} In its third weekend, the film stayed at number two, grossing $15.8 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?yr=2014&wknd=26&p=.htm |title=Weekend Box Office Results for June 27-29, 2014 |website=Box Office Mojo |date=March 7, 2014 |accessdate=July 4, 2014}} In its fourth weekend, the film dropped to number three, grossing $9.8 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?yr=2014&wknd=27&p=.htm |title=Weekend Box Office Results for July 4-6, 2014 |website=Box Office Mojo |date= |accessdate=July 13, 2014}} ===Critical response=== On [[Rotten Tomatoes]] the film has an approval rating of 85% based on 207 reviews, with an average rating of 7/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "Boasting even more of the bromantic chemistry between its stars -- and even more of the goofy, good-natured humor that made its predecessor so much fun – ''22 Jump Street'' is the rare sequel that improves upon the original."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/22_jump_street/ |title=22 Jump Street |website=Rotten Tomatoes |date=June 8, 2014 |accessdate=March 25, 2015}} On [[Metacritic]], the film has a weighted average score of 71 out of 100, based on 46 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/22-jump-street |title=22 Jump Street Reviews |work=Metacritic |date= |accessdate=August 14, 2014}} Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "A−" on an A+ to F scale.{{cite web|url=https://www.cinemascore.com |title=CinemaScore |work=cinemascore.com }} Inkoo Kang of ''[[The Wrap]]'' gave the film a positive review, saying "If ''22'' isn't as trim and tight as its predecessor, it's certainly smarter and more heartfelt. Whether this sequel is better than the original is up for debate, but the franchise has definitely grown up."{{cite web|url=http://www.thewrap.com/22-jump-street-review-channing-tatum-jonah-hill/ |title='22 Jump Street' Review: Channing Tatum and Jonah Hill Star in a Funnier, Smarter, Sexier Sequel |website=TheWrap |date= |accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Chris Nashawaty of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave the film a B−, saying "Hill's neurotic-motormouth act and Tatum's lovable-lunkhead shtick still shoot giddy sparks."{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20824999,00.html |title=22 Jump Street Review | Movie Reviews and News |publisher=EW.com |date= |accessdate=June 14, 2014 |first=Chris |last=Nashawaty}} Claudia Puig of ''[[USA Today]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "This is the ultimate meta movie. The repetition is exactly the point."{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2014/06/11/22-jump-street-review/9649089/ |title='22 Jump Street' bromance takes amusing leap backward |publisher=Usatoday.com |date=December 20, 2013 |accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Kyle Smith of the ''[[New York Post]]'' gave the film two out of four stars, saying "What's the difference between ''21 Jump Street'' and ''22 Jump Street''? Same as the difference between getting a 21 and a 22 at blackjack."{{cite news|last=Smith |first=Kyle |url=https://nypost.com/2014/06/11/lame-22-jump-street-is-a-forced-copycat-of-the-original/ |title=Lame ’22 Jump Street’ is a forced copycat of the original |publisher=Nypost.com |date= June 11, 2014|accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Jocelyn Noveck of the [[Associated Press]] gave the film three out of four stars, saying "Hill and Tatum ... have a Laurel-and-Hardy-like implausible chemistry that keeps you laughing pretty much no matter what they're doing."{{cite web|first=Joceyln |last=Noveck |url=http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2014/jun/11/review-inspired-comic-chemistry-in-22-jump-st/ |title=Review: Inspired comic chemistry in '22 Jump St' |work=U-T San Diego |date= |accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Bill Goodykoontz of ''[[The Arizona Republic]]'' gave the film four out of five stars, saying "What makes it all work is the chemistry between Hill and Tatum, which in turn, of course, is a rich source of the film's humor."{{cite web|url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/entertainment/movies/2014/06/11/movie-review-22-jump-street-stars/10331511/ |title=Review: '22 Jump Street,' 4 stars |publisher=Azcentral.com |date=January 4, 2014 |accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Michael Phillips of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "The peculiar sweetness of ''21 Jump Street'' has taken a hiatus in ''22 Jump Street'', a brazen sequel that's both slightly disappointing and a reliable, often riotous 'laffer' in the old ''Variety'' trade-magazine parlance."{{cite news|first=Michael |last=Phillips |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/movies/ct-22-jump-street-review-20140612,0,7660915.column |title=22 Jump Street movie review |publisher=chicagotribune.com |date= June 12, 2014|accessdate=June 14, 2014}} [[Peter Travers]] of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "''22 Jump Street'' is damn funny, sometimes outrageously so. It laughs at its own dumb logic and invites us in on the fun."{{cite web|first=Peter |last=Travers |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/22-jump-street-20140612 |title='22 Jump Street' Movie Review |publisher=Rolling Stone |date= |accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Joe Neumaier of the ''[[New York Daily News]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "Like its stars, ''Jump Street'' gets extra credit for getting by on charm while sticking to the rules."{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/movies/22-jump-street-movie-review-article-1.1827451 |title=‘22 Jump Street,’ movie review |publisher=NY Daily News |date= June 12, 2014|accessdate=June 14, 2014 |location=New York}} Ian Buckwalter of [[NPR]] gave the film a seven out of ten, saying "What separates ''22 Jump Street'' from sequel mediocrity is that everyone's in on the joke."{{cite web|last=Buckwalter |first=Ian |url=https://www.npr.org/2014/06/12/321331054/familiarity-but-no-contempt-the-sequel-says-jump-you-say-oh-hi?ft=1&f=1045 |title=Familiarity But No Contempt: The Sequel Says 'Jump,' You Say 'Oh, Hi!' |publisher=NPR |date= |accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Sean Fitz-Gerald of ''[[The Denver Post]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "''Jump Street'' knows you know about the predictability and cheapness of sequels and rip-offs – and in this case, to avoid the downfalls of other summer comedy sagas, embracing that problem might have been the best move for this absurd, unique franchise."{{cite news|last=Fitz |first=Sean |url=http://www.denverpost.com/movies/ci_25944592/review-22-jump-street-jonah-hill-slings-self |title="22 Jump Street": Jonah Hill slings self-aware comedy |publisher=The Denver Post |date= June 13, 2014|accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Betsy Sharkey of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' gave the film a positive review, saying "This sequel's spoof of its predecessor's riff on the original 1980s-era buddy-cop TV show coalesces into a raucous, raunchy, irreverent, imperfect riot."{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/la-et-mn-22-jump-street-review-20140613-column.html |title='22 Jump Street' pokes its R-rated finger at everything — hilariously – Los Angeles Times |publisher=Latimes.com |date= June 12, 2014|accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Ty Burr of ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' gave the film three and a half stars out of four, saying "Lord and Miller are on a roll, and there may be no better moviemakers at playing to our modern need for irony – at giving us the entertainment we crave while acknowledging our distrust of it."{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/movies/2014/06/12/jump-street-deconstructs-that-useless-hollywood-artifact-blockbuster-sequel/UySIuZcYppYnonkOnKB3AO/story.html |title=‘22 Jump Street’ deconstructs that useless Hollywood artifact the blockbuster sequel – Movies |publisher=The Boston Globe |date= |accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Rene Rodriguez of the ''[[Miami Herald]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "There's something going on at the edges of the frame in practically every scene of ''22 Jump Street'', a testament to the care and attention to detail directors Lord and Miller bring to this potentially silly material."{{cite web|last=Rodriguez |first=Rene |url=http://www.miami.com/03922-jump-street039-r-article |title='22 Jump Street' (R) |publisher=miami.com |date= |accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Stephen Whitty of the ''[[Newark Star-Ledger]]'' gave the film two and a half stars out of four, saying "At what point is sarcasm just a cheap substitute for wit? Exactly when does joking about how all sequels are just lame, repetitive cash-grabs start to suggest that maybe yours is, too? Actually, in this case, about 40 minutes in."{{cite web|first=Stephen |last=Whitty |work=The Star-Ledger |url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2014/06/22_jump_street_review_channing_and_tatum_cop_to_cashing_in.html |title='22 Jump Street' review: Channing and Tatum cop to cashing in |publisher=NJ.com |date= |accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Bill Zwecker of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "Though I enjoyed enormously this latest offering in the rebooted Jump franchise, it's the effortless, unexpected bromance/partnership between the two unlikely undercover cops is what makes this franchise work."{{cite news|url=http://www.suntimes.com/entertainment/movies/28002839-421/22-jump-street-jonah-hill-channing-tatum-chemistry-makes-it-work.html |title=‘22 Jump Street’: Jonah Hill-Channing Tatum chemistry makes it work – Chicago Sun-Times |publisher=Suntimes.com |date= |accessdate=June 14, 2014}} [[James Berardinelli]] of [[ReelViews]] gave the film two and a half stars out of four, saying "There are times when ''22 Jump Street'' is borderline brilliant. Unfortunately, those instances are outnumbered by segments that don't work for one reason or another."{{cite web|url=http://www.reelviews.net/php_review_template.php?identifier=2773 |title=Reelviews Movie Reviews |publisher=Reelviews.net |date= |accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Jaime N. Christley of ''[[Slant Magazine]]'' gave the film two out of four stars, saying "As funny and batshit insane as the movie often is, the fact that ''22 Jump Street'' knows it's a tiresome sequel doesn't save it from being a tiresome sequel, even as Lord and Miller struggle to conceal the bitter pill of convention in the sweet tapioca pudding of wall-to-wall jokes."{{cite web|url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/film/review/22-jump-street |title=22 Jump Street | Film Review |publisher=Slant Magazine |date=June 9, 2014 |accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Scott Tobias of [[The Dissolve]] gave the film three and a half stars out of five, saying "''22 Jump Street'' squeezes every last drop of comic inspiration it can get from Tatum and Hill, as well as the very notion of a sequel to such a superfluous enterprise."{{cite web|last=Tobias |first=Scott |url=http://thedissolve.com/reviews/862-22-jump-street/ |title=22 Jump Street / The Dissolve |publisher=Thedissolve.com |date= |accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Steve Persall of the ''[[Tampa Bay Times]]'' gave the film a B, saying "''22 Jump Street'' is a mixed bag of clever spoofery and miscalculated outrageousness. The unveiled [[homoeroticism]] of practically all interaction between Jenko and Schmidt is amusing to the point when it isn't."{{cite web|first=Steve |last=Persall |url=http://www.tampabay.com/things-to-do/movies/review-22-jump-street-sequel-is-best-when-mocking-its-flaws/2183924 |title=Review: '22 Jump Street' sequel is best when mocking its flaws |publisher=Tampabay.com |date= |accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Ann Hornaday of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' gave the film three out of five stars, saying "This is a sequel that wears its well-worn formula, mocking inside jokes and gleeful taste for overkill proudly, flying the high-lowbrow flag for audiences that like their comedy just smart enough to be not-too-dumb."{{cite news|last=Hornaday |first=Ann |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/goingoutguide/movies/22-jump-street-review-the-right-way-to-come-back-for-more/2014/06/11/55b9a3a4-f19a-11e3-914c-1fbd0614e2d4_story.html |title=‘22 Jump Street’ review: The right way to come back for more |publisher=The Washington Post |date= June 12, 2014|accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Scott Foundas of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' gave the film a positive review, saying "''22 Jump Street'' hits far more often than it misses, and even when it misses by a mile, the effort is so delightfully zany that it's hard not to give Lord and Miller an 'A' for effort."{{cite news|first=Scott |last=Foundas |url=https://variety.com/2014/film/reviews/film-review-22-jump-street-1201208607/ |title=’22 Jump Street’ Review: Channing Tatum, Jonah Hill Return for Sequel |work=Variety |date=June 2, 2014 |accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Peter Howell of the ''[[Toronto Star]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "If it seemed Channing Tatum and Jonah Hill couldn't possibly exceed their over-the-top buddy cop antics of ''21 Jump Street'', you lost that bet."{{cite news |url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/movies/2014/06/12/22_jump_street_laughs_at_itself_again_review.html |title=22 Jump Street laughs at itself, again: review |publisher=Thestar.com |date=July 25, 2012 |accessdate=June 14, 2014 |location=Toronto}} Tom Long of ''[[The Detroit News]]'' gave the film a B-, saying "There's no real reason ''22 Jump Street'' should work. Yet it does."{{cite web|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/article/20140613/ENT02/306130021 |title=Review: No reason '22 Jump Street' should work – but it does |publisher=The Detroit News |date=March 6, 2014 |accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Joe Williams of the ''[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "A self-aware sequel has to hop over hurdles to keep from swallowing its own tail, but the sharp writing and tag-team antics lift ''22 Jump Street'' to a high level."{{cite web|last=Williams |first=Joe |url=http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/movies/reviews/cop-satire-jump-street-is-more-of-the-same-/article_0a76e93c-83c0-5f40-9e8f-b022f4aa6c4e.html |title=Cop satire '22 Jump Street' is more of the same — and that's not bad |publisher=Stltoday.com |date= |accessdate=June 14, 2014}} Mick LaSalle of the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "''22 Jump Street'' is exactly what comedy is today. It's coarse, free-flowing and playful."{{cite news|first=Mick |last=LaSalle |url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/22-Jump-Street-review-A-comedy-classic-5547827.php |title='22 Jump Street' review: A comedy classic |publisher=SFGate |date= June 12, 2014|accessdate=June 14, 2014}} In 2016, James Charisma of ''[[Playboy]]'' ranked the film #13 on a list of ''15 Sequels That Are Way Better Than The Originals''.{{cite web | title = Revenge of the Movie: 15 Sequels That Are Way Better Than The Originals | publisher = [[Playboy]] | url = http://www.playboy.com/articles/15-sequels-better-than-the-original | author = Charisma, James | date = March 15, 2016 | accessdate = July 19, 2016 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160726093750/http://www.playboy.com/articles/15-sequels-better-than-the-original | archive-date = July 26, 2016 | dead-url = yes | df = mdy-all }} ===Home media=== ''22 Jump Street'' was released on DVD and Blu-ray on November 18, 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.blu-ray.com/news/?id=14941|title=22 Jump Street Blu-ray|work=Blu-ray.com|accessdate=September 27, 2014}} ==Sequel and spin-offs== On September 10, 2014, ''23 Jump Street'' was confirmed.{{cite web |url=http://screenrant.com/23-jump-street-movie-details-director/ |title='23 Jump Street' in the Works; No Director(s) Attached Yet |publisher=ScreenRant.com |date=September 10, 2014 |author=Chris Aga}} Channing Tatum had yet to sign on to the project, stating, "I don't know if that joke works three times, so we'll see."{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/channing-tatum-debates-23-jump-741625|title=Channing Tatum Debates '23 Jump Street': "I Don't Know If That Joke Works Three Times"|last=Lee|first=Ashley|date=October 17, 2014|publisher=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=January 25, 2015}} On August 7, 2015, it was revealed that Lord and Miller would not direct the film, but instead write and produce. A first draft of the film's script has been completed.{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/new/21-Jump-Street-Franchise-Needs-Find-Someone-Take-Over-75887.html|title=The 21 Jump Street Franchise Needs To Find Someone New To Take Over|last=Wakeman|first=Gregory|date=August 7, 2015|publisher=Cinemablend.com|accessdate=August 8, 2015}} On December 10, 2014, it was revealed that Sony was planning a crossover between ''[[Men in Black (franchise)|Men in Black]]'' and ''Jump Street''. The news was leaked after [[Sony Pictures Entertainment hack|Sony's system was hacked]]{{cite news|last1=FRITZ|first1=BEN|title=Sony Plans ‘Men in Black’ – ‘Jump Street’ Crossover|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2014/12/10/sony-plans-men-in-black-jump-street-crossover/|accessdate=December 11, 2014|publisher=wsj.com|date=December 10, 2014}} and then confirmed by the directors of the films, [[Phil Lord and Christopher Miller|Chris Miller and Phil Lord]], during an interview about it.{{cite web|last1=Converse|first1=Simon|author2=Eric Eisenberg|title=M.I.B./Jump Street crossover unofficially confirmed|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/new/Wait-Men-Black-21-Jump-Street-Crossover-Might-Actually-Happen-69170.html|publisher=Cinemablend|accessdate=January 19, 2015|date=January 14, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2016/3/4/11163926/report-23-jump-street-will-be-a-crossover-with-men-in-black|title=Report: 23 Jump Street will be a crossover with Men in Black|publisher=Polygon|last=Alexander|first=Julia|date=March 4, 2016}} [[James Bobin]] was announced as the [[Film director|director]] in March 2016.[http://io9.gizmodo.com/that-21-jump-street-men-in-black-crossover-is-actually-1762984300/ That 21 Jump Street-Men In Black Crossover Is Actually Happening]{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/04/13/trainspotting-2-elizabeth-banks-charlies-angels-jump-street-men-black|title=Sony confirms Charlie's Angels reboot, Jump Street-Men in Black crossover|publisher=entertainment Weekly|last=Franich|first=Darren|date=April 13, 2016|accessdate=April 13, 2016}} The title of the crossover was later revealed as ''MIB 23'', and it was revealed that the crossover would replace a ''23 Jump Street'' film. However, development has since appeared to cease.http://ew.com/article/2016/08/10/jonah-hill-23-jump-street-men-black-crossover/amp/https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/men-in-black-spin-off-confirmed-official-release-date-21-jump-street-crossover-will-smith-returning-a7976686.html?amp In early 2015, a female-driven ''21 Jump Street'' film was rumored to also be in the works. In December 2016, Rodney Rothman was confirmed to make his directorial debut on the film.{{cite news|title=Female-Driven 21 Jump Street Spinoff Rumored to be in the Works|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/435387-female-driven-21-jump-street-spinoff-rumored-to-be-in-the-works#/slide/1|work=comingsoon.net}}{{cite news|title=Rodney Rothman To Direct Female Driven Jump Street Spinoff|url=http://deadline.com/2016/12/21-jump-street-spinoff-female-cops-rodney-rothman-write-direct-sony-pictures-1201862982/}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Portalbar|2010s|Film in the United States|Comedy}} * {{official website}} * {{IMDb title}} * {{mojo title}} * {{rotten-tomatoes}} * {{metacritic film}} {{21 Jump Street}} {{Phil Lord and Christopher Miller}} {{DEFAULTSORT:22 Jump Street}} [[Category:21 Jump Street]] [[Category:2014 films]] [[Category:2010s action films]] [[Category:2010s comedy films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American action comedy films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Phil Lord and Christopher Miller]] [[Category:American buddy films]] [[Category:American buddy cop films]] [[Category:Films scored by Mark Mothersbaugh]] [[Category:Films based on television series]] [[Category:Films shot in New Orleans]] [[Category:Films about fraternities and sororities]] [[Category:Screenplays by Jonah Hill]] [[Category:Self-reflexive films]] [[Category:Police comedy films]] [[Category:American sequel films]] [[Category:American satirical films]] [[Category:Media Rights Capital films]] [[Category:Columbia Pictures films]] [[Category:Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer films]] [[Category:Original Film films]] [[Category:Buddy comedy films]] [[Category:Buddy cop films]]

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; remove 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
'''Abigail Child''' is a filmmaker, poet, and writer who has been active in experimental writing and media since the 1970s.<ref name="Abbott">{{cite news|first=J. Samuel |last=Abbott |title=Alumni Watch: Abigail Child '68 |url=http://www.harvardcrimson.net/article.aspx?ref=509620 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130221214347/http://www.harvardcrimson.net/article.aspx?ref=509620 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-02-21 |work=[[The Harvard Crimson]] |date=2005-11-03 |accessdate=2008-10-20 }}</ref> She has completed more than thirty film and video works and installations, and six books. An acknowledged pioneer in montage, Child’s early film work addressed the interplay between sound and image through reshaping narrative tropes, prefiguring many concerns of contemporary film and media.
==Academics== In 1968, Abigail Child graduated from [[Radcliffe College]] in [[Harvard University]] with a degree in history and literature.<ref name="Abbott"/> She has received a [[Guggenheim Fellowship]] in Film.<ref name="Petrolle">{{cite book |title=Women and Experimental Filmmaking |last=Petrolle |first=Jean |author2=Wexman, Virginia |year=2005 |publisher=[[University of Illinois Press]] |isbn=0-252-03006-0 |pages=20–21 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9dhrewnXgrcC&pg=PA20&dq=Mob+%22Scatter+Matrix%22+%22Abigail+Child%22 }}</ref> She has taught at several universities, including [[New York University]], [[Massachusetts College of Art]], and [[Hampshire College]].<ref name="Janine">{{cite book |title=Fluid Screens, Expanded Cinema |last=Marchessault |first=Janine |author2=Lord, Susan |year=2007 |publisher=[[University of Toronto Press]] |isbn=0-8020-9297-7 |pages=341 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lijmSHqczhwC&pg=PA341&dq=%22From+Solids%22+%22Abigail+Child%22 }}</ref> She has been the chair of Film and Animation department at the [[School of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston]] since 2000<ref name="Janine"/> and was appointed to a fellowship at the [[Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study]].<ref name="Abbott"/> In 2009, she was awarded the [[Rome Prize]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aarome.org/sites/sofa/2009-2010/abigail-child |title=Abigail Child |year=2009 |work=[[American Academy in Rome]] |accessdate=2010-06-09 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qMqTvIGw?url=http://www.aarome.org/sites/sofa/2009-2010/abigail-child |archivedate=2010-06-09 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
== Career in film, writing, and poetry == Child began making films in the 1970s, producing seven independent documentaries shot on 16mm.<ref name="Abbott"/> From the middle of the 70s she turned to experimental montage and in the 80s her work explores gender and strategies for remaking narrative.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmvideo.walkerart.org/detail.wac?id=2682&title=Articles |title=Query: Abigail Child |accessdate=2008-10-20|work=[[Walker Art Center]] |date=February 2006 }}</ref> ''Is This What You Were Born For?'' is a major, seven-part experimental work from this period, completed over nine years, which included the cult classics ''Mayhem'' and ''Covert Action''.<ref name="Haynes">{{cite news|first=Todd|last=Haynes|title=A Queer Kind of Film|url=http://afterimage.carpe-datum.com/afterimage/articles/detail/513537|work=Afterimage|date=Dec 1988}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name="Stuart">{{cite news |title=none|first=Jan |last=Stuart |work=Film Comment |volume=23 |issue=6|date=Nov–Dec 1987}}</ref><ref name="Foster">{{cite book |title=Women Film Directors |last=Foster |first=Gwendolyn Audrey |year=1995 |publisher=[[Greenwood Publishing Group]] |isbn=0-313-28972-7 |page=74 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-kJHa7KqnQ4C&pg=PA74&lpg=PA74&dq=Perils+%22Abigail+Child%22&source=web&ots=cjNN_9cYYB&sig=Le4wGaW5lHaW8lL44i4pud59oCQ&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=7&ct=result}}</ref> (see Filmography). In the 90s Child poetically envisioned and interrogated public spaces in such films as ''B/side''(1996), about urban homelessness on the Lower East Side of New York city, and ''Below the New: A Russian Chronicle'' (1999), filmed in St. Petersburg.<ref>{{cite news |first=Jeffrey |last=Skoller |title=Home sweet home.(Abigail Child's 1996 documentary film 'B/side') |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-53436065.html |work=Afterimage |date=1998-11-01 |accessdate=2008-10-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smfa.edu/Programs_Faculty/Faculty/C/Child_Abigail.asp |title=SMFA Boston - Abigail Child |accessdate=2008-10-20 |work=[[School of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011043201/http://www.smfa.edu/Programs_Faculty/Faculty/C/Child_Abigail.asp |archivedate=11 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="etc">These artworks can be found in {{cite web|title=The repository of the Experimental Television Center|url=http://hdl.handle.net/1813.001/8946249a|website=[[Experimental Television Center]]- [[Rose Goldsen Archive of New Media Art]]|publisher=[[Cornell University Library]]|accessdate=24 June 2015}}</ref>
In the 21st century, Child’s film and video has explored history, memory, and cultural experiences—the politics of place and identity. Digital works like ''Cake + Steak'' (2004) and ''The Future Is Behind You'' (2005)<ref name="etc">These artworks can be found in {{cite web|title=The repository of the Experimental Television Center|url=http://hdl.handle.net/1813.001/8946249a|website=[[Experimental Television Center]]- [[Rose Goldsen Archive of New Media Art]]|publisher=[[Cornell University Library]]|accessdate=24 June 2015}}</ref> investigate the awkward drama of the everyday, often utilizing found material to examine the past. ''Mirror World'' (2006) is a multi-screen installation that incorporates parts of Child’s “foreign film” series to explore narrative excess. Key works include ''Surface Noise'' (2000), ''Dark Dark'' (2001), ''Where The Girls Are'' (2002), ''Cake and Steak'' (2004), ''The Future Is Behind You'' (2004), ''To and No Fro'' (2005), and ''Mirror World'' (2006). Her feature video documentary ''On The Downlow'' (2007)), is an exploration of bisexuality and an intimate look at a little-viewed underground scene.
In 2012, Child completed a feature film, ''Shape of Error,'' an imaginary “home movie” based on the diaries of Mary Shelley during her marriage with Percy Shelley.
Child is also the author of five books of poetry (published between 1983 and 2012) <ref name="Petrolle"/><ref name="Janine"/> and a book of critical writings: ''This Is Called Moving: A Critical Poetics of Film'' (2005).
A collection of writings by various authors on ''Is This What You Were Born For?'', including a DVD of the film series, was published in 2011.{{fact|date=April 2016}}
==Filmography<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abigailchild.com/index.php?/films/filmography/|title=Filmography : ABIGAIL CHILD|website=abigailchild.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref>== {{unreferenced|section|date=April 2016}} * Acts and Intermissions (2017) * Salome (2014) * ELSA {{proper name|merdelamerdelamer}} (2012)<ref>https://mubi.com/cast/abigail-child</ref> * Unbound (2012) * A Shape Of Error (2011) feature film on Mary and Percy Shelley * The Suburban Trilogy (2011) film and digital * Riding the Tiger: Letters from Capitalist China (2010-2014) * Hacking Empire (2010) single screen version of ''L'Impero Invertito'' * If I Can Sing A Song About Ligatures (2009) w/ Nada Gordon, ''Foreign Film Series'' * Surf And Turf (2008-2011) 16mm/digital, ''The Suburban Trilogy, part 3'' * On The Downlow (2007) Digital feature documentary, dir. by Child; ed: Yael Bitton; Camera: Arthur Jafa * Mirror World (2006) 16mm to digital, w/ Gary Sullivan ''Foreign Film Series'' * To And No Fro (2005) 16mm to digital, w/ Monica de la Torre. ''Foreign Film Series'' * Blonde Fur (2004) Loop from ''Cake and Steak'' * The Party (2004) * The Future Is Behind You (2004) film/digital, ''The Suburban Trilogy, Part 2'' * Cake and Steak (2003–04) film/digital, ''The Suburban Trilogy, Part 1'' * The Milky Way (2003) Installation version of ''Dark Dark'' * Subtalk (2002) digital, w/ [[Benton C Bainbridge]] and Eric Rosenzveig <ref>https://books.google.com/books?id=XFCJrLHhxWcC&pg=PA368&lpg=PA368&dq=bainbridge+child+rosenzveig+subtalk&source=bl&ots=R7p5BRWudI&sig=Liwf-2hmVJTYndGdkXEIoAFi39M&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjOq-e62NvTAhUEMyYKHWJpCvQQ6AEISjAH#v=onepage&q=bainbridge%20child%20rosenzveig%20subtalk&f=false</ref> * Dark Dark (2001) film, ''How the World Works, Part 2'' * Surface Noise (2000) film, ''How the World Works, Part 1'' * Below the New (1999) * Her Thirteenth Year (screenplay) (1998) * B/SIDE (1996) film * Dinkinsville (1994) video * Through The Looking Lass ''w/ L. Champagne'' & Songs (1993) interactive video performance * Songs (1993) interactive video performance w/[[Benton C Bainbridge]], Vicky Funari and [[Ikue Mori]] * 8 Million (1992) video album w/ Ikue Mori) * Swamp (1990–91) w/ S. Schulman * Mercy (1989) ''Is This What You Were Born For? Part 7'' * Both (1988) ''Is This What You Were Born For? Part 3'' * Mayhem (1987) ''Is This What You Were Born For? Part 6'' * Perils (1985–86) ''Is This What You Were Born For? Part 5'' * Covert Action (1984) ''Is This What You Were Born For? Part 4'' * Mutiny (1982–83) ''Is This What You Were Born For? Part 2'' * Prefaces (1981) ''Is This What You Were Born For? Part 1'' * Ornamentals (1979) * Pacific Far East Line (1979) * Peripeteia II (1978) * Daylight Test Section (1978) * Peripeteia I (1977) * Some Exterior Presence (1977) * Tar Garden (1975)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abigailchild.com/index.php?/books/climateplus/|title=Climate/Plus : ABIGAIL CHILD|website=abigailchild.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref> * Mother Movie (1973) * Game (1972) w/Jon Child * Except The People (1970) w/Jon Child
==Publications== * ''Is this what you were born for?'' (MetisPresses, 2011)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abigailchild.com/index.php?/books-1/|title=Is This What You Were Born For? : ABIGAIL CHILD|website=abigailchild.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref> * ''This is Called Moving: A Critical Poetics of Film'' ([[University of Alabama Press]], 2005)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abigailchild.com/index.php?/books/this-is-called-moving/|title=This is Called Moving : ABIGAIL CHILD|website=abigailchild.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref> * ''Counter Clock'' (Tout Court Editions, Mermaid Tenement Press, 2009)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abigailchild.com/index.php?/books/counter-clock/|title=Counter Clock : ABIGAIL CHILD|website=abigailchild.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref> * ''Artificial Memory'' ([[Belladonna Books|Belladonna Press]], 2001)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abigailchild.com/index.php?/books/artificial-memory/|title=Artificial Memory : ABIGAIL CHILD|website=abigailchild.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref> * ''Flesh'' poems for Sarah Shulman by Abigail Child (Published by ZET Amsterdam - New York 1990)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abigailchild.com/index.php?/books/flesh/|title=Flesh : ABIGAIL CHILD|website=abigailchild.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref> * ''Scatter Matrix'' (Roof Books, 1996)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abigailchild.com/index.php?/books/scatter-mix/|title=Scatter Matrix : ABIGAIL CHILD|website=abigailchild.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref> * ''Mob'' (O Books, 1994)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abigailchild.com/index.php?/books/mob/|title=Mob : ABIGAIL CHILD|website=abigailchild.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref> * ''A Motive for Mayhem'' (Potes & Poets, 1989)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abigailchild.com/index.php?/books/a-motive-for-mayhem/|title=A Motive for Mayhem : ABIGAIL CHILD|website=abigailchild.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref> * ''Climate Plus'' (Coincidence Press: Second Season, 1986)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abigailchild.com/index.php?/books/climateplus/|title=Climate/Plus : ABIGAIL CHILD|website=abigailchild.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref> * ''From Solids'' (Roof Books, 1983)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abigailchild.com/index.php?/books/from-solids/|title=From Solids : ABIGAIL CHILD|website=abigailchild.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://abigailchild.com Official website] * {{IMDb name|id=0157450|name=Abigail Child}} * {{Amg name|198525}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081011043201/http://www.smfa.edu/Programs_Faculty/Faculty/C/Child_Abigail.asp Biography at School of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston]
{{Authority control}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use British English|date=July 2015}} :''For the [[Arthur (TV series)|Arthur]] character also known as The Brain, see [[List of Arthur characters]].''
'''Alan Powers''' (born 1955) is a [[United Kingdom|British]] teacher, researcher and writer specialising in architecture and design.
Powers trained as an [[art historian]] at [[University of Cambridge]], gaining an undergraduate degree and a PhD.
As a writer Powers has been prolific, writing reviews, magazine articles, obituaries of artists and architects as well as books. He has concentrated on 20th century [[British architecture]] and architectural conservation. He has also written books on the design of book jackets, shopfronts, book collectors, and the artist [[Eric Ravilious]] as well as monographs on [[Serge Chermayeff]], and the British firms of Tayler and Green and of Aldington, Craig and Collinge. He is joint editor of the journal Twentieth Century Architecture published by the [[Twentieth Century Society]], and joint editor of the series of monographs, Twentieth Century Architects, published by RIBA and [[English Heritage]] with the Twentieth Century Society. In 2011-12, Powers was awarded a Mid Career Fellowship by the [[British Academy]] to study 'Figurative Architecture in the Time of Modernism', a study of non-modernist architecture in Britain.
He has curated several popular exhibitions, including Modern Britain 1929-39 [[Design Museum]], 1999, Serge Chermayeff ([[Kettle's Yard]]), 2001, Eric Ravilious ([[Imperial War Museum]]), 2003 and Mind into Matter ([[De La Warr Pavilion]]), 2009. His exhibition 'Eros to the Ritz: 100 years of street architecture' is at the [[Royal Academy]], London, 2012/3.
Alan Powers was until recently Professor of Architecture and Cultural History at the [[University of Greenwich]] in London.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070712125838/http://w3.gre.ac.uk/schools/a-and-c/staff/staffdir.html] He currently teaches at the London campus of [[New York University]].
He is Chairman of [[Pollock's Toy Museum]] Trust, London and formerly Chair of the [[Twentieth Century Society]] (2007–2012). He remains involved in the Society's campaigns for education and conservation.
In 2008 Powers was elected to an Honorary Fellowship of the [[Royal Institute of British Architects]] ([[RIBA]]) in recognition of his standing as one of the pre-eminent experts in the history of 20th-century architecture.
==Selected books== * ''Serge Chermayeff: Designer, Architect Teacher [[RIBA]] London, 2001 {{ISBN|978-1859460757}}. * ''[[Eric Ravilious]]: Imagined Realities'', [[Philip Wilson Publishers]], 2003. {{ISBN|978-0-85667-567-6}}. * ''Twentieth Century Houses in Britain: From the Archives of "[[Country Life (magazine)|Country Life]]"'', [[Aurum Press]], 2004. {{ISBN|978-1-84513-012-1}}. * ''Modern: The Modern Movement in Britain'', Merrell Publishers, 2005. {{ISBN|978-1-85894-255-1}}. * ''Front Cover: Great Book Jacket and Cover Design'', [[Mitchell Beazley]], 2006. {{ISBN|978-1-84533-242-6}}. * ''Britain: Modern Architectures in History'', [[Reaktion Books]], 2007. {{ISBN|978-1-86189-281-2}}. * ''Art and Print: the Curwen Story'', [[Tate Publishing Ltd|Tate]], 2008. {{ISBN|978-1-85437-721-0}} * ''Aldington, Craig and Collinge'', [[RIBA Publishing]], 2009. {{ISBN|978-1-85946-302-4}} * ''Robin Hood Gardens Re-Visions'', Twentieth Century Society, 2010. {{ISBN|978-095566-871-5}} * ''British Murals and Decorative Painting 1920-1960,London 2014 {{ISBN|978-1-908326-23-2}}
